Monina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store selling a variety of food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than three years earning 3,000 PHP monthly from her business. In 2006, Monina joined PMPC to access its programs and services. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Union Group

texts.es:
Bethzabe C. de 30 años es integrante del grupo Unión que  realiza sus reuniones cada dos semanas en el Centro Focal German Busch, ella conjuntamente con su esposo se dedican a la elaboración de muebles o mejor conocido como carpintería,  su esposo antes de casarse con ella, ya trabajaba en el taller de su padre, una vez que se ha independizado decidieron juntos poner el taller de carpintería y así han estado trabajando hace 4 años, tienen dos puntos de venta una ubicada en la 16 de Julio y otra en la zona Ballivián, ambos tienen las ganas de seguir con el negocio y mejorar por lo que necesitan el préstamo para comprar material como madera y clavos al por mayor.

Las demás integrantes del grupo tienen el negocio de venta de accesorios de celulares, plásticos, productos de belleza y antigüedades y necesitan el negocio para incrementar su capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Bethzabe C. is a member of the Union Group, which meets every two weeks at the German Busch Community Center. She and her husband work together to manufacture furniture. Her husband is known for his carpentry skills and worked in his father’s shop before they got married. As soon as they decided to work independently, Bethzabe and her husband opened their own woodworking shop and have now been in business for four years. They operate two vending locations, one in the July 16th district and the other in the Ballivián district. Both of them desire to continue and improve their business, so they need a loan to purchase materials in bulk such as wood and nails.

The other group members have businesses selling mobile phone accessories, plastics, beauty products, and antiques. They need a loan to increase their operating capital.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Fidelia

texts.es:
Fidelia es una socia dinámica, vive en el distrito de Yarina Cocha, región de Ucayali. Ella tiene 38 años de edad, es madre de dos hijos(1 de ellos mayor de edad) y cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien se dedica a la extracciòn de madera. 
Fidelia se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, por lo que compra los productos y posteriormente distribuye en los caseríos alejados de la ciudad de Pucallpa. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Perlas de Pucallpa” desde hace cinco años y el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300.00 nuevos soles con los que comprò cajas de gaseosas para venderlas.
En la actualidad necesita un crédito de 600.00 nuevos soles que serán utilizados en la compra de productos como: arroz, leche, azúcar, fideos, etc. para poesteriormente venderlas. 
La meta de Fidelia es tener un local estable de abarrotes y productos en general.
texts.en:
Fidelia is a dynamic member of her community bank; she lives in the Yarina Cocha district in the region of Ucayali. She is 38 years old, the mother of two children (one of them is an adult), and has the support of her husband who works in logging. Fidelia sells groceries, so she buys products and later distributes them in the villages outside the city of Pucallpa. She has been a member of the "Perlas de Pucallpa" Community Bank for five years, and her first loan was for 300 soles to buy carton of soft drinks to sell. Now, she is requesting a loan for 600 soles that she will use to buy products such as rice, milk, sugar, pasta, etc. to sell. Fidelia's goal is to have a permanent grocery and general store.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
With skills in watch and cellular phone repair is our featured entrepreneur. He is Mr. Jerry D., 33 years of age, single, and a resident of P5 Maquilao, Tangub City. He has one minor dependent.

Jerry started his watch and cellphone repair business six years ago during the time he was in Manila City and for two years he has established his own repair shop in this city. He is earning an average net income of 11,000 PHP a month at this time and is also receiving a daily income of 150 PHP from his for-hire motor-cab.

Jerry joined Paglaum MPC just this year because he is very much interested in our products and services and for our being one of the most outstanding cooperative in Northern Mindanao and the awarded coop for being “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award, 2006.

As a new member under the regular loan program, Jerry is given the privilege of obtaining 50,000 PHP to add to his capital for purchasing cellphone and watch accessories and spare parts. He is also adding to his cellphone repair equipment.

Jerry’s future plan is to establish another repair outlet. He is also planning to settle down for marriage next year.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for purchasing cellphone accessories and watch spare parts

loans.name: Los Comerciantes De Virgen Asunta Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LOS COMERCIANTES DE VIRGEN ASUNTA” situado en la ciudad del Cusco, en el distrito de Iscuchaka, provincia de Anta departamento del Cusco. 

Nuestros socios son 11 miembros dentro de este banco comunal, ellos alternan sus diferentes actividades con el comercio, la mayoría de nuestros socios se dedican al a pasamanería, ellos tiene su diferentes stands en la feria de Anta en Iscuchaka, a 1 hora y 20 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco, nuestros socios venden en sus stands desde pasadores para atar, betún de zapatos, pinzas, espejos, cables eléctricos, ligas, peines, escobillas, cordeles, tijeras, jaboncillos, pasta dental, agujetas, cortaúñas y un sinfín de cosas de pasamanería. Otros 2 socios compran y venden zapatos y zapatillas al por mayor y menor; Todos los socios solicitan el préstamo para reinvertir en sus diferentes negocios y seguir su crecimiento y de este modo apoyar a su familia.

Nuestros socios agradecen y les hacen llegar  un enorme abrazo y un cordial saludo y los mejores deseos para este nuevo año y se comprometen n cumplir con los pagos de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our members belong to the communal bank, "Los Comerciantes de Virgen Asunta," which is located in the city of Cusco, in the district of Iscuchaka, in the province of Anta, in the department of Cusco. We have thirteen members in this communal bank. They have different businesses. The majority of them sell items for domestic use. They have different stands in the Anta market in Isuchaka, which is 1 hour and 20 minutes from the city of Cusco. Our members sell items at their stands like shoelaces, shoe polish, pins, mirrors, electronic cables, rubber bands, combs, brushes, cords, scissors, soap, toothpaste, and nail clippers, Two members buy and sell shoes and slippers both wholesale and retail. All of the members are requesting a loan to reinvest in their different businesses and to keep growing them so they can support their families. Our members thank you and send you a giant hug and friendly hello and wish you the best for this new year. They promise to make their payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise for domestic use as well as shoes and slippers to sell at their different stands

loans.name: Rene

texts.es:
Rene vive en la zona  Villa Dolores de la ciudad de El Alto, en su casita propia. 

Trabaja en una pequeña imprenta la cual es de su propiedad y se encuentra ubicada en una de las zonas céntricas de la ciudad.

Su esposa le colabora en sus trabajos diarios en el taller.

El crédito lo destinará a la compra de materiales (papel, tinta) para el buen desempeño de sus trabajos.

Es el séptimo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Rene live in the Villa Dolores zone of the city of El Alto, in his own home. He works in a small printing shop which he owns and which is located in one of the central zone of the city. His wife helps him in his daily work in his shop. He will use the loan for the purchase of materials (paper, ink) to perform his work well. This is his seventh loan from Impro. The completed evaluation qualifies him to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials such as paper and ink for his print shop

loans.name: Familia Unida De Inversiones 6 Group

texts.en:
Justino is the coordinator of his group Familia Unida D. Inversion (United Family of Investments), and his story is representative of his group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. His group is located in the slums surrounding Santiago, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. He makes his home here in a simple structure with his long-term partner and their two children.

Justino is excited to be taking his third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid his previous loan and expanded his business. He plans to use this loan to invest in his small colmado (convenience store) by supplying it with the basics such as rice, beans, cooking oil and sugar. He will use the profits to invest in his children's future by purchasing their school supplies. Additionally, he plans to save towards his goal of someday owning a supermarket. He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: beans, rice, cooking oil and sugar

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen B. has been married for 31 years. She is a rice grower from Norala, South Cotabato. She has five children. The income that she gets from growing rice has helped her family a lot—in buying food and meeting other basic needs. Now, she has a little problem in financing her rice farm, which is why she needed to apply for a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
With her belief and faith in coming out from under the umbrella of poverty, Josefina decided to join Kiva partner, ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), in 2000. It provided her with an opportunity of accessing start-up capital for income-generating activities. With her first loan from ASHI, she carefully invested in her sari-sari store (a small retail store selling different goods). She uses the profits for daily expenses.
Now on her third loan, Josefina is requesting 15,000 PHP to create a broader business. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase additional supplies for her sari-sari store, such as cases of beers, soft drinks, and other stocks. She is very determined and disciplined in her use of the loan.
Josefina still dreams of the best for her family: to provide the best education for her grandchildren and to have a happy family. During the course of her membership in ASHI, she has shown herself to be industrious and determined to make her dreams come true.
Josefina is a 54-year-old business-minded woman. Her husband passed away so she is now the single mother of her daughter, Janett. She lives in Pililia, in the province of Rizal, Philippines. She belongs to a poor family that needs help to improve its standard of living and she is grateful to ASHI for support in all the challenges of life.

About ASHI
Ahon sa Hirap Inc., or ASHI, has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen methodology to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. ASHI, as the first practitioner in the field, saw how poor women and mothers worked hard to earn money for their family and provide their children with a better life. Since the microcredit ASHI is extending to these women is delivered directly in their villages on the doorsteps of their houses, they are given the hope that someday they will “rise above poverty” (a translation of Ahon Sa Hirap, in English.)

loans.use: To purchase cases of beers, soft drinks, and other stocks

loans.name: Idania Ya Jaira .

texts.es:
En el barrio Francisco Reyes   Municipio de Somotillo 
La señora G. P. realiza su trabajo como agente de ventas en la empresa de Almacenes tropigas atendiendo alos clientes que diariamente los visitan de las diferentes comarcas como alos del casco urbano del municipio de Somotillo
 Ella  quiere el crédito para comprar de  20 bolsas de cemento de 5 quintales de hierro   para la construcción de una pared en su casa de habitación y de esta manera tener una mejor seguridad para ella y  su familia.
texts.en:
In the Francisco Reyes neighborhood, part of the Somotillo Municipality, Mrs. G. P. works as a sales agent in the Tropigas (cooking gas) Warehouse. She takes care of customers who visit daily from different areas such as the city center of the Somotillo Minicipality. She would like the loan in order to buy 20 bags of cement and 5 hundred-weight of iron. These will be used to build a wall around her house and in this way obtain greater security for herself and her family.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 bags of cement, 5 hundred-weight of iron and the workers wages in order to build a wall in her house.

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en:
Rosaline K. is married to John Mutai, and they have been blessed with four children, Emmanuel Tabut, Christine Jeptoo, Miriam Jerotich, and Esther Chebichi. They both practice agriculture on their farm and mainly specialize in maize cultivation. She sells her farm produce in small quantities to local customers within her area of residence. She has been doing this for six years.

Rosaline was introduced to KADET by her friend who was already an existing member. She has applied for a loan which she will use to prepare her one acre of land and buy phosphate fertilizers so that she can plant maize and use part of the money to open a retail shop.

She hopes that with the proceeds from the shop she will be able to pay school fees for her children when they join secondary school.

loans.use: To cultivate one acre of maize on her farm (at 6,000 KES) and use the remainder to open a retail shop (kiosk)

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es:
Nuestra socia pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCIÓN”; Nuestra socia vive en el distrito de Anta provincia de Anta departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. MARCELINA,  ella tiene 56 años de edad, es casada y tiene 2 menores hijos, Nuestra socia alterna su trabajo con el comercio minorista, ella compra y vende animales menores y vende comidas en la plaza central de Anta todos los días, Nuestra socia se dedica a este negocio desde hace 10 años. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar ingredientes para elaborar comidas y vender. 

La socia agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our member belongs to the VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCION community bank and lives in Anta in the Peruvian "departamento" of Cusco. Her name is Sra. Marcelina. She is 56 years old and married with 2 children, both minors. She does many things to make a living: she operates a corner shop; she buys and sells animals; and she goes out every day to sell prepared food in Anta's central plaza. Marcelina has operated this business for more than 10 years. She is applying for a loan so that so that she can buy ingredients for making the prepared dishes she sells. Marcelina is grateful for the support offered by this measure and is committed to repaying the loan in the agreed-upon time.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for food business.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina Q. is a 53-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Olympia, Bais City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by fishing, fish vending and pig fattening. Justina’s 55-year-old husband, Wilfredo, is a fisherman, and they have five children who are between 13 and 30 years old. One of their children works as a Loan Officer and is presently assigned in Santander Branch Cebu. Two of the children currently go to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.
Justina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF, she has been able to increase her family income by engaging in fishing, fish vending and pig fattening. Now she earns an average monthly income of 9,000 PHP from her business activities.
Justina is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP was used to fund the operation of her fishing business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing 18,000 PHP for her 14th loan, which she intends to use on fishing, fish vending and pig fattening. Justina is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Dancy Rosa

texts.es:
Dancy tiene 26 años de edad, es casada y tiene dos hijos, uno en edad escolar y otro menor; vive junto a su familia en el caserío Granja Sasape, una zona rural y agrícola situada en el distrito de Túcume, conocido por ser uno de los principales ejes turísticos de la región gracias a la abundancia de ruinas que datan de periodos anteriores a los Incas, pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y se encuentra ubicado a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de tres años a la venta de platos típicos de la zona y de chicha (bebida típica de la zona hecha a base de maíz), ella ofrece estos productos en su domicilio y los vende a los pobladores y trabajadores de la zona en donde vive, el negocio es su principal fuente de ingresos por lo que trata de mantenerlo dando lo mejor de si.

Adicionalmente se dedica a la crianza y venta de cabritos, con este negocio obtiene un igreso adicional que es de mucha importancia para su familia. Ella desea implementar con sillas el local donde vende comida para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes, por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Dancy es una joven trabajadora y que siempre busca la manera de ayudar a su familia a salir adelante, su mayor anhelo es lograr instalar un pequeño restaurante para poder percibir mas ingresos y mejorar su calidad de vida. En la imagen aparece junto a los cabritos que comercializa.
texts.en:
Dancy is 26 years old. She is married and has two children; one is schoolaged and one is younger. She lives with her family in the hamlet of Granja Sasape, a rural and agricultural area located in the district of Túcume. It is known for being one of the main tourist hubs in the region, thanks to its abundance of ruins that date from the Incas. It belongs to the province of Lambayeque and it is located an hour from the city of Chiclayo. For more than three years, she has been selling traditional food from the area and chicha (a traditional drink of the area made from a corn base). She offers these products from her home and sells them to villagers and workers in the area where she lives. The business is her main source of income and she tries to maintain it, giving the best of herself. She also raises and sells young goats. With this business she obtains additional income, which is very important to her family. She wants to outfit the locale where she sells the food with chairs in order to offer better service to her customers. This is why she has found it necessary to ask Edpyme Alternativa for a loan for the first time, for 1000 nuevos soles. Dancy is a hardworking young woman who is always looking for the way to get her family ahead. Her greatest wish is to be able to set up a little restaurant to be able to have more income and improve her quality of life. The goats that she sells appear in the image.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase chairs to outfit her restaurant.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda L. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 53 years old, married and has 7 adult-aged children. Linda owns and operates a farming business, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Linda has been engaged in her business for over 30 years.

Linda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Linda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm materials. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Linda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm materials

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a 34 year old woman who is a member of Faulu Kenya under Bukima Lady’s group.  She saves her money with the group on a weekly basis.  This has helped her to improve her business. She has been guaranteed a loan of 20,000 KES by the group members. 

Rachael opened a salon a year ago.  Currently, she has many customers because of her good service. She hopes to expand her salon and add salon equipment in order to provide better service.  With this loan, Rachael will purchase a hairdryer, a blow-drier and other hair products.

loans.use: To purchase hair drier, hair blow drier and hair products.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 48 years old and married. To make a living, Concepcion has farmed rice for over 20 years. Concepcion joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepcion has successfully repaid previous loans from CEVI and now requests her 10th loan, for 20000 PHP, tol be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For general farm supplies and equipment.

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.es:
Bernardina nació en la ciudad D. Cachimayo y tiene 52 años. Actualmente, Luz Marina vive en la  misma ciudad junto con su esposo y sus 6 hijos. La ciudad D. Cachinayo se encuentra ubicada a 25 minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco.   

Bernardina se dedica a la venta D. leche D. forma ambulatoria en la ciudad del Cusco, ella recorre las calles D. la ciudad del cusco ofreciendo leche, tres veces a la semana desD. las 3 D. la tarD. hasta las 5 D. la noche. Los días domingos lleva a vender comida a la plaza principal D. Cachimayo. La pueden encontrar en su puesto D. venta, desD. las 9 D. la mañanas hasta 3 D. la tarD. o hasta se termine la comida. 

Con su próximo préstamo, Bernardina que espera recibir S/. 700 nuevos soles. Le gustaría emplear el dinero del préstamo para comprar leche y insumos como por ejemplo arroz, carne, papa, cebollas, tomates, etc.

El banco comunal “Señor D. Ccoyllority Cachimayo” tiene tres años y medio D. funcionamiento, Bernardina pertenece desD. hace tres años al banco comunal y le va muy bien. Los socios D. este lugar son devotos del Taytacha Ccoyllority (El señor D. la Nieve Brillante) y por esa razón le pusieron el nombre al banco comunal.
texts.en:
Bernardina was born in the city of Cachimayo and is 52 years old. Luz Marina lives in the same city, along with her husband and six children. Cachimayo is located 25 minutes from Cusco. Bernardina sells milk on foot in Cusco, buy walking through the city streets three times a week from 3:00 PM to 5:00 PM. On Sundays she sells food in the main Cachimayo plaza. One can find her at her stall from 9:00 AM to 3:00 PM, or until her food runs out. Bernardina is hoping for a loan of 700 PEN ($250). She wants to use the money to buy milk and ingredients, such as rice, meat, potatoes, onions, tomatoes, etc. The “Señor D. Ccoyllority Cachimayo” communal bank has been operating for three years. Bernardina has been a member for three years and things are going well for her. Its members are devotees of the “Taytacha Ccoyllority (El señor D. la Nieve Brillante)” church, so they chose this name for their communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Milk and ingredients

loans.name: Ose Roberto

texts.es:
José tiene 30 años de edad. Reside en el Municipio de Santa Elena, Departamento de Usulután, es casado, vive con la esposa y dos hijos de las edades 2y 5 años, el posee una tienda de venta de productos de primera necesidad.
El negocio surgió gracias a la iniciativa de esposo quien le dio la idea de poner el negocio, el atiende el negocio en un horario de 7:00am -6:00pm una de la dificultades que tiene es que no cuenta con el dinero para invertir en la compra de productos. El solicita un préstamo para compra de mercadería como son aceite, azúcar, frijoles, arroz, sopas instantáneas, entre otros, esto le permitirá crecer en el negocio ya que podrá satisfacer en el negocio ya que podrá satisfacer la demanda a los clientes, incrementar las ventas, los riesgos es que los costos se eleven, bajen las ventas, mejorar las condicione de vida de la familia.
Los sueños de José son crecer el negocio y apoyar a su joven familia a solventar las necesidades atreves del trabajo.
texts.en:
José is 30 years old. He lives in the town of Santa Elena in Usulután province. He is married, and they live with their two children aged 2 and 5 respectively. He has a convenience store. The business began thanks to his wife's initiavive; she gave him the idea for the business. He runs the shop from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. One problem he has is that he does not have the money to invest in his inventory. He is applying for a loan in order to purchase merchandise like cooking oil, sugar, beans, rice, and instant soup. These purchases will allow him to grow his business because he will better fulfill his clients demands and increase his sales. The risks are that the cost of products will rise or that sales will go down. He hopes to improve his family's condition. Jose's dreams are to grow his business and support his young family by fulfilling their needs.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise like cooking oil, sugar, beans, rice, and instant soup

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian C. is a 28-year-old supplier of eggs and mineral water in Bamburi, Mombasa. She is married to Victor Mbera, who supports her income, and together they are blessed with three children. 

Lilian has been in this business for the last two years and she has been successful.

Having been introduced to KADET LTD., she is now requesting her first loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase more trays of eggs and use the anticipated profit to start up a retail shop.

In the future, she hopes to succeed in her business through KADET LTD. loans and also improve the standard of living of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more trays of eggs

loans.name: Kurbon

texts.en: Kurbon M. has always been dedicated to agriculture together with his wife. He is 48 years old, married and has six children. As his activity has always been focused on making the land produce, the loans he has requested have generally been spent on necessary supplies to obtain good production. At the same time, Kurbon is also engaged in cattle breeding. Kurbon needs a loan of 9,000 Somoni to go on purchasing farming supplies for his crops and small cattle for breeding. In the future, Kurbon expects to have his own working capital, which will allow him to cover the costs and buy more land in order to increase production and grow as a farmer. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer and small cattle

loans.name: Estilita's Group

texts.en:
Estilita V. is from the village of Villa Luna,Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 44 years old. Estilita is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Estilita is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Estilita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Estilita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Estilita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estilita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Estilita is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Estilita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita J. is a 73-year-old woman from Centro Poblacion, Culasi, Antique, Philippines.  She is married to Jesus J. who is 72 years old.  All of their children have their own families and their own houses.

Although she is 73 years old, she is still strong enough to run her business and is mature in dealing with problems.

Estelita and Jesus are both industrious and work hand in hand in order to survive without depending on their children.  Actually, they are the ones who help their children and grandchildren.

The buying and selling of salt is their primary source of income, but sometimes during the fishing season she also engages in fish vending. 

Her loan from ASHI is a big help for them because through the capital entrusted to them, they earn an income and through their income they are able to afford their needs and wants. They already have their own business stalls in the market. Moreover, these businesses not only give them an income, but they also provide pleasure to her.  

She is applying for a 10,000.00 PHP loan. This amount will be utilized as additional capital to help her buy and sell more salt. She hopes that someday she can become a wholesaler of salt for the entire municipality.

loans.use: To buy more salt to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, age 24, owns and runs a grocery store in a busy part of Nairobi. Her business has a good number of loyal customers. She has been in this business for five years, before which she was in the business of selling used clothing. She is social and hardworking and hopes eventually to be a distributor of fruits and vegetables on a larger scale. 

She is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to purchase passionfruits, bananas, and avocados, and to enlarge her business premises.

Mary and her husband have three children.

loans.use: To purchase passionfruits, bananas, and avocados, and to enlarge her business premises

loans.name: Joby

texts.en: Joby C. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, detergents, sugar by the kilogram, instant noodles and junk foods in her community. She is 31 years old, married and has two school-aged children. They are from the village of Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. Joby has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Joby joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Joby has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Joby is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Progresando En Valores 1, 2, 3 Group

texts.en:
Ysabel is the coordinator of her group, Progresando en valores 1, 2, 3 (progress in values). She makes her home in a simple structure with her long-term partner and four children. She says that her most difficult challenge is to finish building a bathroom in her house. In the meantime she continues to enjoy sewing.

Ysabel is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza. She has had her business, which she started with some savings, for two years. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying clothing and a sewing machine. She will use the profits to build a bathroom and a kitchen. Her dreams are to work hard and move her business forward, and with the help of God, she will.

This Esperanza associate began with us because she wanted to invest in her business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's other Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients. Her group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a nascent tourism industry. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: To buy clothing and a sewing machine

loans.name: Telmo Washington

texts.es:
Telmo Washington Q. G. tiene 35 años. Es casado, vive con la esposa y los hijos, vive en el cantón de San Miguel en la Provincia de Bolívar. Tiene 3  hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C SOLIDARIOS CHIMA CHICA se encuentra ubicada A 30 minutos de la Oficina San Miguel, perteneciente al cantón San Miguel, esta ventanilla se dedica a la agricultura como fuente de ingresos familiares, siembra maíz y en pocas cantidades las papas y el fréjol.

Telmo  se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y papas. Compra sus productos en Ambato,  Quito y  San Miguel y los vende en la feria de San Miguel los días jueves.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos agrícolas y pago a los jornaleros. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es comprar terrenos para seguir sembrando.

Le gusta ir a misa los domingos.
texts.en:
Telmo Washington Q. G. is a 35-year-old married man. He lives with his spouse and children in San Miguel county in Bolivar province. He has three children.

The members of the Solidarios Chima Chica communal bank are located thirty minutes from our San Miguel office in San Miguel county. The members of this group work as farmers in order to earn income for their families. They grow corn and a small amount of potatoes and beans.

Telmo works as a farmer and plants corn and potatoes. He buys his products in Ambato, Quito, and San Miguel, and sells his goods at the Thursday market in San Miguel.

He is requesting this loan in order to buy farming supplies and to pay day laborers. With financial assistance from this loan, Telmo will be able to supply himself with basic necessities. Telmo faces challenges such as insect infestations, diseases, and changes in the weather. His dream is to buy land so that he can continue growing crops.

He enjoys going to mass on Sundays.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies and to pay day laborers.

loans.name: Eddie

texts.en:
Eddie O. is 25 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Eddie has a phone accessories shop, which he has run for less than a year.
To help expand his business, Eddie has requested a loan of 1,600,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more phone accessories. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Eddie hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, he hopes to own another house.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories for resale

loans.name: William Xavier

texts.es: William tiene 33 años. Se dedica es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 5 años que tiene experiencia en su negocio, por lo que es un hombre muy responsable y disfruta de su actividad. William sabe que tiene que levantarse temprano para ofrecerles a sus clientes una gran variedad de productos, el recorrido que realiza es de manera ambulante ya que es así que obtiene mas ganancias. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de  calzado, cosméticos, ropa en general entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
William is 33 years old and has been selling general merchandise for more than five years. He is a very responsible gentleman who enjoys his work. William knows that he must wake up early so that he can offer his customers a wide variety of products. He travels a route as a street vendor so that he can generate the most income.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy shoes, cosmetics, general clothing, and other items.

loans.use: Operating capital to buy merchandise

loans.name: Grimaldina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal” LA ÑUSTA III”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Calca, perteneciente a la provincia de Calca y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Graciela; ella tiene 33 años de edad, casada y tiene 3 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de tienda de abarrotes ella vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar y leche entre otro tipos de productos más su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su misma casa, la socia a la vez trabaja en un wawawasi (lugar donde se quedan los niños mientras sus papas trabajan guardería) ella trabaja de lunes a viernes por las mañanas y en las tardes se encarga de su tienda de esta forma la socia saca a su familia adelante.

La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de más mercadería para su tienda de abarrotes y así poder tener más variedad para ofrecer a sus clientes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Sra. Grimaldina belongs to the Communal Bank “La Ñusta III”, which is located in the District and Province of Calca, Department of Cusco.

She is 33 years old, married, and has three children. Grimaldina divides her time between her daily activities and her grocery business where she sells basic necessity products such as rice, sugar, milk, and many other items. She works Monday through Friday in the mornings at a day care center where parents leave their children while at work. In the afternoons, Grimaldina manages her store so that her family can get ahead. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy more merchandise for her grocery store so that she can have a wider variety to offer to her customers.

Grimaldina is happy with the loan and promises to complete all of her payments.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for her grocery store

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 27 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tasses, de galettes, de chaussures et de tubercules.  Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire.                                                                                MAMAN T. compte acheter, des ustensiles avec les grossistes du marché de Barouéli hebdomadairement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women in the Benkadi group are all married, are on average 27 years old with two children and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Siemana, part of the Barouéli prefecture in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of Mali).

They got acquainted through ties of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. They sell mugs, cakes, shoes, and tubers. The women in the Benkadi group are on their sixth cooperative loan.

Mom T. intends to buy utensils from wholesalers at the weekly market in Barouéli. She makes daily sales locally at home and in the market, for cash and credit to a largely female clientele.

She expects to attain a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to reimburse the loan, pay contributions towards social ceremonies and the rest will be reinvested in her business activity.

loans.use: Buy utensils
